(7 titles) }} [[File:Sign for African Nations Cup.jpg|thumb|240px|right|Sign during the [[2010 Africa Cup of Nations|2010 edition of the tournament in Angola]]]] The '''Africa Cup of Nations''', also referred to as the '''African Cup of Nations''' or '''African Nations Cup''', officially '''CAN''' ([[French language|French]] for ''Coupe d'Afrique des Nations''), is the main international [[association football]] competition in [[Africa]]. It is sanctioned by the [[Confederation of African Football]] (CAF), and was first held in [[1957 Africa Cup of Nations|1957]]. Since [[1968 Africa Cup of Nations|1968]], it has been held every two years. The title holders at the time of a [[FIFA Confederations Cup]] qualify for that competition. In 1957 there were only three participating nations: [[Egypt national football team|Egypt]], [[Sudan national football team|Sudan]] and [[Ethiopia national football team|Ethiopia]]. [[South Africa national football team|South Africa]] were originally scheduled to compete, but were disqualified due to the [[apartheid]] policies of the government then in power.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/africa/cup_of_nations/1709599.stm African Cup of Nations - How it all began] BBC Sport, 14 December 2001 Since then, the tournament has grown greatly, making it necessary to hold a qualifying tournament. The number of participants in the final tournament reached 16 in 1998 (16 teams were to compete in 1996 but [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]] withdrew, reducing the field to 15), and since then, the format has been unchanged, with the sixteen teams being drawn into four groups of four teams each, with the top two teams of each group advancing to a "knock-out" stage. [[Egypt national football team|Egypt]] is the most successful nation in the cup's history, winning the tournament a record seven times (including when Egypt was known as the [[United Arab Republic]] between 1958 and 1971). [[Ghana national football team|Ghana]] and [[Cameroon national football team|Cameroon]] have won four titles each. Three different trophies have been awarded during the tournament's history, with [[Ghana national football team|Ghana]] and [[Cameroon national football team|Cameroon]] winning the first two versions to keep after each of them won a tournament three times. The current trophy was first awarded in 2002 and with [[Egypt national football team|Egypt]] winning it indefinitely after winning their unprecedented third consecutive title in 2010. As of 2013, the tournament will switch to being held in odd-numbered years so that it does not clash with the [[FIFA World Cup]].{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/africa/8685251.stm | work=BBC News | title=Nations Cup switched to odd years | date=16 May 2010}} ==History== ===1950s-60s: Early growth of the ANC competition=== The origins of the African Nations Cup date back to June 1956, when the creation of the Confederation of African Football was proposed during the third [[FIFA]] congress in [[Lisbon]]. There were immediate plans for a continental nations tournament to be held, and in February 1957, the [[1957 African Cup of Nations|first African Cup of Nations]] took place in [[Khartoum]], [[Sudan]]. There was no qualification for this tournament, the field being made up of the four founding nations of CAF (Sudan, Egypt, Ethiopia, and South Africa). South Africa's insistence on selecting only [[Caucasian race|caucasian]] players for their squad due to that nation's [[apartheid]] policy led to its disqualification, and as a consequence Ethiopia were handed a bye straight to the final. {{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/africa/cup_of_nations/1709599.stm | author=BBC News | publisher=[[BBC]] | title=African Nations Cup - How it all began | accessdate=9 March 2007 | date=14 December 2001}} Hence, only two matches were played, with Egypt being crowned as the first continental champion after defeating hosts Sudan in the semi-final and Ethiopia in the final. Two years later, Egypt hosted the second ANC in [[Cairo]] with the participation of these same three teams. Host and defending champions Egypt repeated as cup winners, this time downing Sudan. The field grew to include nine teams for the [[1962 African Cup of Nations|third ANC in 1962]] in [[Addis Ababa]], and for the first time there was a qualification round to determine which four teams would play for the title. Host Ethiopia and reigning champion Egypt received automatic berths, and were joined in the final four by [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]] and [[Tunisia national football team|Tunisia]]. Egypt made its third consecutive final appearance, but it was Ethiopia that emerged as victors, after first beating Tunisia and then downing Egypt in [[Extra time (football)|extra time]]. ===1960s: Ghanaian domination=== In 1963, [[Ghana national football team|Ghana]] made its first appearance as it hosted the event, and won the title after beating Sudan in the final. They repeated that as they became champions two years later in [[Tunisia]] â equalling Egypt as two-time winners â with a squad that included only two returning members from the 1963 team. {{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/africa/3396199.stm | author=BBC Sport | publisher=[[BBC]] | title=The early years | accessdate=9 March 2007 | date=16 January 2004}} The [[1968 African Cup of Nations|1968 competition's]] final tournament format expanded to include eight of the 22 teams entered in the preliminary rounds. The qualifying teams were distributed in two groups of four to play single [[round-robin tournament]]s, with the top two teams of each group advancing to semi-finals, a system that remained in use for the finals until 1992. The [[Congo DR national football team|Democratic Republic of Congo]] won its first title, beating Ghana in the final. Starting with the 1968 tournament, the competition has been regularly held every two years in even numbered years. [[CÃ´te d'Ivoire national football team|CÃ´te d'Ivoire]] forward [[Laurent Pokou]] led the 1968 and 1970 tournaments in scoring, with six and eight goals respectively, and his total of 14 goals remained the all-time record until 2008. Play was covered for television for the first time during the [[1970 African Cup of Nations|1970 tournament]] in Sudan, as the hosts lifted the trophy after defeating Ghana â who were playing their fourth consecutive final. ===1970s: A decade of champions=== Six different nations won titles from 1970 to 1980: [[Sudan national football team|Sudan]], [[Republic of the Congo national football team|Congo-Brazzaville]], [[Zaire national football team|Zaire]], [[Morocco national football team|Morocco]], Ghana, and Nigeria. Zaire's second title in the [[1974 African Cup of Nations|1974 edition]] (they won their first as the Democratic Republic of Congo) came after facing [[Zambia national football team|Zambia]] in the final. For the only time to date in the history of the competition, the match had to be replayed as the first contest between the two sides ended in a 2-2 draw after extra time. The final was re-staged two days later with Zaire winning 2-0. Forward [[Mulamba Ndaye]] scored all four of Zaire's goals in these two matches: he was also the top scorer of the tournament with nine goals, setting a single-tournament record that remains unmatched. Three months earlier, Zaire had become the first black African nation to qualify to the [[FIFA World Cup]]. Morocco won their first title in the 1976 ANC held in Ethiopia and Ghana took its third championship in 1978, becoming the first nation to win three titles. In 1980, [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]] hosted the event and beat [[Algeria national football team|Algeria]] to capture its first honours. ===1980s: Cameroonian and Nigerian domination=== Ghana's fourth continental title came in the [[1982 African Cup of Nations|1982 cup tournament]]; they beat Algeria in the semi-finals in extra time, and faced host [[Libya national football team|Libya]] in the final. The match ended in a 1-1 draw after 120 minutes and Ghana won the [[penalty shootout (football)|penalty shootout]] to become champions. Cameroon won their first title two years later by beating Nigeria and in the [[1986 African Cup of Nations|1986 cup]] they faced Egypt â absent from the final since 1962 â with Egypt winning the title on penalty kicks. Cameroon reached its third consecutive final in the [[1988 African Cup of Nations|1988 tournament]] and won their second championship by repeating their 1984 victory over Nigeria. In 1990, Nigeria lost once again as they made their third final appearance in four tournaments, this time falling to Algeria. ===1990s: The return of South Africa=== The [[1992 African Cup of Nations|1992 Cup of Nations]] expanded the number of final tournament participants to 12; the teams were divided into four groups of three, with the top two teams of each group advancing to quarter-finals. [[Ghana]]ian [[midfielder]] [[AbÃ©di PelÃ©|Abedi "PelÃ©" Ayew]], who scored three goals, was named the best player of the tournament after his contributions helped Ghana reach the final; he was, however, suspended for that match and Ghana lost to CÃ´te d'Ivoire in a penalty shootout that saw each side make 11 attempts to determine the winner. CÃ´te d'Ivoire set a record for the competition by holding each of their opponents scoreless in the six matches of the final tournament. The 12-team, three-group format was used again two years later, where hosts [[Tunisia national football team|Tunisia]] were humiliated by their first round elimination. [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]], who had just qualified to the World Cup for the first time in their history, won [[1994 African Cup of Nations|the tournament]], beating [[Zambia national football team|Zambia]], who a year before had been struck by disaster when most of their national squad died in a [[Zambia national football team#Gabon air disaster|plane crash]] while traveling to play a [[1994 FIFA World Cup qualification (CAF)|1994 World Cup qualification]] match. Nigerian forward [[Rashidi Yekini]], who had led the 1992 tournament with four goals, repeated as the top scorer with five goals. [[South Africa]] hosted the [[1996 African Cup of Nations|20th ACN competition]] in 1996, marking their first ever appearance after a decades long ban was lifted with the end of apartheid in the country and a failed attempt to qualify in 1994. The number of final round participants in 1996 was expanded to the current 16, split into four groups. However, the actual number of teams playing in the final was only 15 as Nigeria withdrew from the tournament at the final moment for political reasons.{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/africa/3736102.stm | author=Mark Gleeson, BBC Sport, Cape Town | publisher=BBC Sport | title=SA to meet Nigeria | accessdate=10 December 2007 | date=12 October 2004}} ''[[South Africa national football team|Bafana Bafana]]'' won their first title on home soil, defeating Tunisia in the final.{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/africa/3399773.stm | author=BBC Sport | publisher=[[BBC]] | title=African Cup of Nations: 1980-2002 | accessdate=11 March 2007 | date=16 January 2004}} The South Africans would reach the final again [[1998 African Cup of Nations|two years later]] in [[Burkina Faso]], but were unable to defend their title, losing to Egypt who claimed their fourth cup. ===2000s: Egypt's unprecedented Treble=== [[File:Sulley.jpg|240px|thumb|right|[[Ghana national football team|Ghana]]'s [[Sulley Muntari]] about to take a free kick at the [[2008 African Cup of Nations|2008 tournament]]]] The [[2000 African Cup of Nations|2000 edition]] was hosted jointly by [[Ghana]] and [[Nigeria]], who replaced the originally designated host [[Zimbabwe]]. Following a 2-2 draw after extra time in the final, Cameroon defeated Nigeria on penalty kicks. In 2002, Cameroon's ''[[Cameroon national football team|Indomitable Lions]]'' made the second consecutive titles since Ghana had done it in the 1960s and after Egypt had done it before in 1957 and 1959. Again via penalty kicks, the Cameroonians beat first-time finalists [[Senegal national football team|Senegal]], who also debuted in the [[2002 FIFA World Cup|World Cup]] later that year. Both finalists were eliminated in quarter finals [[2004 African Cup of Nations|two years later]] in [[Tunisia]], where the hosts won their first title, beating Morocco 2-1 in the final. The [[2006 African Cup of Nations|2006 tournament]] was also won by the hosts, [[Egypt national football team|Egypt]], who reached a continental-record fifth title. The [[2008 African Cup of Nations|2008 tournament]] was hosted by [[Ghana]], and saw Egypt retain the trophy, winning their record-extending sixth tournament by defeating Cameroon 1-0 in the final.{{cite news | date=10 February 2008 | url=http://arogeraldes.blogspot.com/2007/10/sorteo-de-la-copa-africana-de-naciones.html| title=Ghana 2008 all results | publisher=[[International football journalism]] | accessdate=10 February 2008}} Egypt set a new record in the [[2010 African Cup of Nations|2010 tournament]] that was hosted by [[Angola]] by winning their third consecutive title in an unprecedented achievement on the African level after defeating [[Ghana national football team|Ghana]] 1-0 in the final, retaining the gold-plated cup indefinitely and extending their record to 7 continental titles (including when Egypt was known as the [[United Arab Republic]] between 1958 and 1971).{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/africa/8489708.stm|title=Ghana 0-1 Egypt |date=2010-01-31|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=2010-01-31}} On 31 January 2010, [[Egypt national football team|Egypt]] set a new African record, not being defeated for 19 consecutive Cup of Nations matches, since a 2-1 loss against [[Algeria national football team|Algeria]] in [[2004 African Cup of Nations|Tunisia in 2004]],{{Citation needed|date=October 2011}} and a record 9 consecutive win streak.{{Citation needed|date=October 2011}} Egypt also set another record on that day, where it became the first African nation to win three consecutive cups joining [[Mexico national football team|Mexico]], [[Argentina national football team|Argentina]], and [[Iran national football team|Iran]] who won their [[continent]] cup 3 times in a row. ===Future=== Ahead of the [[2008 Africa Cup of Nations]] several European clubs called for a rethink of the tournament's schedule. As it takes place during the European season, players who are involved miss several matches for their clubs. {{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/africa/7140013.stm | author=BBC Sport | publisher=[[BBC]] | title=African Nations Cup - Possible changes | accessdate=14 December 2007 | date=12 December 2007}} In January 2008, [[FIFA]] president [[Sepp Blatter]] announced that he wanted the tournament to be held in either June or July by 2016, to fit in the international calendar, although this would preclude many countries in central and west Africa from hosting the competition (as these months occur during their [[wet season]]).{{cite news | date=18 January 2008 | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/africa/7194966.stm| title=Blatter wants Cup of Nations move | publisher=[[BBC Sport]] | accessdate=18 January 2008}} In May 2010, it was announced that the tournament would be moved to odd-numbered years from 2013. This will mean the tournament will not take place in the same year as the [[FIFA World Cup|World Cup]]. It also means there will be two tournaments within twelve months in January 2012{{cite web|title=Equatorial Guinea: Ahead of AU Summit, Government Curtails Political Rights, Disregards Social Needs|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201106221328.html|work=Press Release|publisher=Human Rights Watch|accessdate=24 June 2011}} (co-hosted by [[Gabon]] and [[Equatorial Guinea]]) and January 2013 (hosted by [[South Africa]]). On the 29th January 2011 [[Morocco]] won the bid to host the [[2015 Africa Cup of Nations|2015]] edition and [[South Africa]] won the right to host the [[2017 Africa Cup of Nations|2017]] tournament. But due to the [[2011 Libyan Civil War]], Libya and South Africa traded years with South Africa hosting in 2013 and Libya hosting in 2017.{{Citation needed|date=October 2011}} ==Trophy== Throughout the history of the Nations Cup, three different trophies have been awarded to the winners of the competition. The original trophy, made of silver, was the '''"Abdelaziz Abdallah Salem Trophy"''', which was named after the first CAF president, the [[Egypt]]ian [[Abdelaziz Abdallah Salem]]. As the first winner of three Nations Cup tournaments, [[Ghana national football team|Ghana]] obtained the right to permanently hold the trophy in 1978. {{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/africa/1562471.stm | author=BBC News | publisher=[[BBC]] | title=Nations Cup trophy revealed | accessdate=16 March 2007 | date=25 September 2001}} The second trophy was awarded from 1980 to 2000, and it was named '''"Trophy of African Unity"''' {{cite web | url=http://www.fifa.com/en/print/article/0,4039,10769,00.html | author=FIFA.com | publisher=[[FIFA]] | title=The Great Adventure of African Football | accessdate=16 March 2007}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} or '''"African Unity Cup"'''. It was given by the Supreme Council for Sports in Africa to the CAF prior to the 1980 tournament and it was a cylindrical piece with the [[Olympic symbols#Olympic rings|Olympic rings]] over a map of the continent engraved on it. It sat on a squared base and had stylized triangular handles. [[Cameroon national football team|Cameroon]] won the Unity Cup indefinitely after they became three-time champions in 2000. In 2001, the third trophy was revealed, a gold-plated cup designed and made in [[Italy]].{{Citation needed|date=October 2011}} Cameroon, permanent holders of the previous trophy, were the first nation to be awarded the new trophy after they won the 2002 edition.
